articles.headline: Panel Faults C.I.A. Over Brutality and Deceit in Terrorism Interrogations
articles.snippet: The scathing report, which took five years to produce, is a sweeping indictment of the C.I.A. interrogation program carried out in secret prisons after the Sept. 11 attacks.
articles.abstract: The scathing report, which took five years to produce, is a sweeping indictment of the C.I.A. interrogation program carried out in secret prisons after the Sept. 11 attacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate Intelligence Committee on Tuesday issued a sweeping indictment of the Central Intelligence Agency’s program to detain and interrogate terrorism suspects in the years after the Sept. 11 attacks, drawing on millions of internal C.I.A. documents to illuminate practices that it said were more brutal — and far less effective — than the agency acknowledged either to Bush administration officials or to the public.

articles.headline: Report Portrays a Broken C.I.A. Devoted to a Failed Approach
articles.snippet: The report paints a devastating picture of an agency that was ill equipped to question terrorism suspects, bungled the job and misrepresented the results.
articles.abstract: The report paints a devastating picture of an agency that was ill equipped to question terrorism suspects, bungled the job and misrepresented the results.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In January 2003, 10 months into the Central Intelligence Agency’s secret prison program, the agency’s chief of interrogations sent an email to colleagues saying that the relentlessly brutal treatment of prisoners was a train wreck “waiting to happen and I intend to get the hell off the train before it happens.” He said he had told his bosses he had “serious reservations” about the program and no longer wanted to be associated with it “in any way.”

articles.headline: Longtime Chief of Bloomberg News to Be Succeeded by The Economist’s Editor
articles.snippet: After nearly 25 years as a dominant force at Bloomberg News, its editor in chief, Matthew Winkler, will become editor in chief emeritus to make way for John Micklethwait.
articles.abstract: After nearly 25 years as a dominant force at Bloomberg News, its editor in chief, Matthew Winkler, will become editor in chief emeritus to make way for John Micklethwait.
articles.lead_paragraph: In September, when Michael R. Bloomberg reassumed control of the company he left while serving three terms as New York City mayor, he met with senior executives to pose a question: Who should replace his longtime editor in chief at Bloomberg News, Matthew Winkler?

articles.headline: Senate Report Rejects Claim on Hunt for Bin Laden
articles.snippet: The Senate Intelligence Committee report on C.I.A. torture disputes the notion that the agency would not have found Osama bin Laden if it had not tortured detainees.
articles.abstract: The Senate Intelligence Committee report on C.I.A. torture disputes the notion that the agency would not have found Osama bin Laden if it had not tortured detainees.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Months before the operation that killed Osama bin Laden in 2011, the Central Intelligence Agency secretly prepared a public-relations plan that would stress that information gathered from its disputed interrogation program had played a critical role in the hunt. Starting the day after the raid, agency officials in classified briefings made that point to Congress.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage and James Risen

articles.headline: In Latin America, Growth Trumps Climate
articles.snippet: In countries like Brazil, where the economy has been slowing, government policy is prioritizing growth over plans to cut carbon emissions.
articles.abstract: In countries like Brazil, where the economy has been slowing, government policy is prioritizing growth over plans to cut carbon emissions.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — Eco-warriors on the front lines of climate diplomacy often frame the environmental conflict between the developed and the developing world as a version of the notorious skirmish between Lawrence H. Summers and José Lutzenberger, which happened on the sidelines of the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro in 1992, widely seen as the official start of the world’s interest in climate change.

articles.headline: Airbag Compound Has Vexed Takata for Years
articles.snippet: For nearly two decades, the company has struggled to tame ammonium nitrate, an inexpensive but unstable compound used to inflate its airbags.
articles.abstract: For nearly two decades, the company has struggled to tame ammonium nitrate, an inexpensive but unstable compound used to inflate its airbags.
articles.lead_paragraph: For nearly two decades, Takata has struggled to tame an inexpensive but unstable compound thought to play a central role in airbag ruptures that are linked to at least five deaths and dozens of injuries.

articles.headline: With New Capital Rule, Fed Nudges Big Banks to Shrink
articles.snippet: The proposed regulation could require JPMorgan Chase, one of the eight large banks targeted, to come up with an additional $20 billion in capital.
articles.abstract: The proposed regulation could require JPMorgan Chase, one of the eight large banks targeted, to come up with an additional $20 billion in capital.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve, fearing complacency six years after the financial crisis, moved on Tuesday to preserve the efforts that have strengthened large banks.

articles.headline: Uber’s System for Screening Drivers Draws Scrutiny
articles.snippet: In statehouses across the country, Uber has fought against legislation requiring background checks as strong as those demanded of traditional taxis.
articles.abstract: In statehouses across the country, Uber has fought against legislation requiring background checks as strong as those demanded of traditional taxis.
articles.lead_paragraph: Uber champions its “industry-leading standards” for vetting its drivers. On its website, it describes its background checks as “often more rigorous” than those in the traditional taxi industry.

articles.headline: It’s Not the Old Days, but Berkeley Sees a New Spark of Protest
articles.snippet: The University of California, Berkeley, campus today is nothing like the one that became the symbol of student activism in the 1960s.
articles.abstract: The University of California, Berkeley, campus today is nothing like the one that became the symbol of student activism in the 1960s.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — This is the college town where the Free Speech Movement was born 50 years ago, spreading across the nation with sit-ins, marches, demonstrations and arrests. So at first glance, the demonstrations against police conduct in Ferguson, Mo., and on Staten Island that gripped Berkeley over the past few days should be no surprise.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney, Carol Pogash and Tamar Lewin

articles.headline: Special K, a Hallucinogen, Raises Hopes and Concerns as a Treatment for Depression
articles.snippet: Some see ketamine as an effective drug for some patients, and others see it as a dangerous hallucinogen that has not been studied enough.
articles.abstract: Some see ketamine as an effective drug for some patients, and others see it as a dangerous hallucinogen that has not been studied enough.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is either the most exciting new treatment for depression in years or it is a hallucinogenic club drug that is wrongly being dispensed to desperate patients in a growing number of clinics around the country.

articles.headline: Obama Catches Blame on Tactics of Torture That He Ended
articles.snippet: The debate over interrogation techniques has left President Obama facing an uncomfortable rift between two allies, the C.I.A. director and Democrats on the committee that produced the report.
articles.abstract: The debate over interrogation techniques has left President Obama facing an uncomfortable rift between two allies, the C.I.A. director and Democrats on the committee that produced the report.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Wednesday found himself caught in the middle of a collision between the Central Intelligence Agency and his own Democratic allies, who accused the White House of helping to cover up a legacy of torture and put the president on the defensive over an interrogation program he never supported.

articles.headline: Appeals Court Deals Setback to Crackdown on Insider Trading
articles.snippet: The federal appeals court decision may portend a broader unraveling of the government’s insider trading crackdown and will also offer a blueprint for lawyers to defend future insider trading cases.
articles.abstract: The federal appeals court decision may portend a broader unraveling of the government’s insider trading crackdown and will also offer a blueprint for lawyers to defend future insider trading cases.
articles.lead_paragraph: The convictions had racked up in recent years, 85 people all told, as Manhattan prosecutors swept through Wall Street with what they described as clear-cut evidence of insider trading.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Matthew Goldstein
